query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
1 Ora era onde ’l salir non volea storpio; 2 ché ’l sole avëa il cerchio di merigge 3 lasciato al Tauro e la notte a lo Scorpio:
4 per che, come fa l’uom che non s’affigge 5 ma vassi a la via sua, che che li appaia, 6 se di bisogno stimolo il trafigge,
7 così intrammo noi per la callaia, 8 uno innanzi altro prendendo la scala 9 che per artezza i salitor dispaia.
query.result:
**English:**
1 Now was the hour when he who climbs could no longer do so; 2 for the sun had left the circle of midday 3 to Taurus, and the night to Scorpio:
4 so that, like a man who does not linger 5 but goes on his way, whatever may appear to him, 6 if the spur of necessity goads him on,
7 thus we entered the narrow path, 8 one going before the other, taking the steps 9 which, because of their narrowness, separate those who climb.
**Cornish:**
1 Le mayth oedh pan vynns an sorpya deges; 2 rag an howl oedh gwrys an keth kresel 3 dhe hwrel dhe Scorpio an nos:
4 rag, kepar del den na wra veth ow synsi, 5 mes a wra dhe'y fordh, pyth vyth a wra gwelys, 6 mar an cusan a wra'y govy,
7 hemma a wrug ni mos dhe fordh kul, 8 unn kyns an kyns ow kemerel an gresen 9 hag a wra dhe'y kuntelles an sorpyer.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
16 Non lasciò, per l’andar che fosse ratto, 17 lo dolce padre mio, ma disse: «Scocca 18 l’arco del dir, che ’nfino al ferro hai tratto».
query.result:
**English:**
16 My gentle father did not stop, for all his rapid pace, 17 but said: "Shoot the arrow of speech, for you have drawn it back to the iron."
**Cornish:**
16 Ny wrug ov lesel, rag an fordh oedh bys, 17 vy fader ker, mes leverel: "Gwayt 18 an saeth a leverel, rag dhe'th gorra dhe'n horn."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
19 Allor sicuramente apri’ la bocca 20 e cominciai: «Come si può far magro 21 là dove l’uopo di nodrir non tocca?».
query.result:
**English:**
19 Then I opened my mouth confidently 20 and began: "How can one become thin 21 where the need to eat does not touch one?"
**Cornish:**
19 Anedhen ow tos ow ben owth dhe leverel 20 ha ow commensis: "Pyth vyth yllir mos colgh 21 le mayth an cusan dhe vaga na wra gov?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
28 Ma perché dentro a tuo voler t’adage, 29 ecco qui Stazio; e io lui chiamo e prego 30 che sia or sanator de le tue piage».
query.result:
**English:**
28 But so that you may be satisfied in your desire, 29 here is Statius; and I call and beseech him 30 that he may now be the healer of your wounds."
**Cornish:**
28 Mes rag dhe vos sodhek dhe vos lowena, 29 gwel, yma Stazius; ha ow'n leverel ha ow pyth 30 dhe vos y'n medhek dhe'whyth col."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
31 «Se la veduta etterna li dislego», 32 rispuose Stazio, «là dove tu sie, 33 discolpi me non potert’ io far nego».
query.result:
**English:**
31 "If I unbind his eternal vision," 32 Statius replied, "there where you are, 33 do not blame me for not being able to refuse you."
**Cornish:**
31 "Mar ow dystyn ow welas tramor dhe'y dhyskwedhes", 32 leverel Stazius, "le mayth os, 33 na'm gwreys vy dhe vos ow tos owth dhe'n ober."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
34 Poi cominciò: «Se le parole mie, 35 figlio, la mente tua guarda e riceve, 36 lume ti fiero al come che tu die.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Then he began: "If my words, 35 my son, your mind heeds and receives, 36 I will be a light to you on the how that you ask about.
**Cornish:**
34 Wosa leverel: "Mar ow leverel vy, 35 vy mab, yw eich poynt ow tos owth ha dhe vos kemerel, 36 ow fia golow dhys war an pyth vyth ow leverel."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
37 Sangue perfetto, che poi non si beve 38 da l’assetate vene, e si rimane 39 quasi alimento che di mensa leve,
40 prende nel core a tutte membra umane 41 virtute informativa, come quello 42 ch’a farsi quelle per le vene vane.
query.result:
**English:**
37 Perfect blood, which is not drunk 38 by the thirsty veins, and remains 39 almost like food that is left over from a meal,
40 takes on in the heart the power to give form to all human limbs, 41 just like that blood 42 which flows through the veins to make them.
**Cornish:**
37 Gwydh berfekth, na wra yevys 38 gans an gwythennow assetys, ha'y trig, 39 kepar boos ow tos owth dhe voos,
40 a wra kemerel y'n kalon dhe bubes oll an den, 41 nerth dhe furvya kepar henna 42 ow tos dre'n gwythennow dhe'y gwreys.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
43 Ancor digesto, scende ov’ è più bello 44 tacer che dire; e quindi poscia geme 45 sovr’ altrui sangue in natural vasello.
query.result:
**English:**
43 Once digested, it descends to where it is more fitting 44 to be silent than to speak; and then afterwards it laments 45 over another's blood in its natural vessel.
**Cornish:**
43 Wosa trewel, y'n kodha le mayth yw 44 dhe dhewi na leverel; ha wosa henna 45 y'n gwela war gwydh aral y'n les naturel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
52 Anima fatta la virtute attiva 53 qual d’una pianta, in tanto differente, 54 che questa è in via e quella è già a riva,
55 tanto ovra poi, che già si move e sente, 56 come spungo marino; e indi imprende 57 ad organar le posse ond’ è semente.
query.result:
**English:**
52 The active virtue made a soul 53 like that of a plant, differing in this much, 54 that the latter is on the way and the former is already at the shore;
55 then it works so much that it moves and feels, 56 like a marine sponge; and from there it begins 57 to organize the powers of which it is the seed.
**Cornish:**
52 Eneval gwres an virtudesober, 53 dellvell eghen plan,yn kethdifferens, 54 henna yw yn fordh hagena yw dheworth,
55 obera kyns henna, pub movia ha sentia, 56 dellvell spuns mor; hagena'gancommenjadh 57 dheorgana an possow lemayth wra semens.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
58 Or si spiega, figliuolo, or si distende 59 la virtù ch’è dal cor del generante, 60 dove natura a tutte membra intende.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Now, my son, the virtue that comes from the heart of the generator unfolds and extends itself, 59 where nature intends to all the members.
**Cornish:**
58 Wosa, mab, an virtudesober yw'gan splanja, yw'gan estenja, 59 lemayth wra yw a galon an generant, 60 lemayth wra natura dhe oll an eseli a'gan entent.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
61 Ma come d’animal divegna fante, 62 non vedi tu ancor: quest’ è tal punto, 63 che più savio di te fé già errante,
64 sì che per sua dottrina fé disgiunto 65 da l’anima il possibile intelletto, 66 perché da lui non vide organo assunto.
query.result:
**English:**
61 But how from an animal it becomes a human being, 62 you do not yet see: this is such a point 63 that a wiser man than you once erred,
64 so that by his doctrine he separated 65 the possible intellect from the soul, 66 because he did not see an organ assumed by it.
**Cornish:**
61 Mes dellvell eghen eneval a dhefens, 62 ny wellys ty hwath: henna yw an point, 63 henna a wreus savyor ages ty a wreus errans,
64 pub travia y dhiskwedhans a wreus disjoynt 65 a'gan enevel a'gan intellekt possebyl, 66 rag na welas ev organ asummet gans.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
67 Apri a la verità che viene il petto; 68 e sappi che, sì tosto come al feto 69 l’articular del cerebro è perfetto,
70 lo motor primo a lui si volge lieto 71 sovra tant’ arte di natura, e spira 72 spirito novo, di vertù repleto,
73 che ciò che trova attivo quivi, tira 74 in sua sustanzia, e fassi un’alma sola, 75 che vive e sente e sé in sé rigira.
query.result:
**English:**
67 Open your breast to the truth that is coming; 68 and know that, as soon as the articulation of the brain is perfect in the fetus,
69 the prime mover turns to it with joy 70 over such artistry of nature, and breathes 71 a new spirit, full of virtue,
72 which draws to itself whatever it finds active there, 73 and makes of it a single soul, 75 that lives and feels and revolves upon itself.
**Cornish:**
67 Egor dhe'gan veritas lemayth wra yw gorra, 68 ha gows henna, pub per feth an fetus 69 an artikular a'gan serebrum yw perfeth,
70 an motor primo dhe'gan volja dhe'gan les 71 warbarth kyns art a natur, ha spira 72 speris nowydh, a vertus repleth,
73 henna a gav henna aktiv lemayth wra, tira 74 yn y substansia, ha fassi un'alma sola, 75 henna a vew ha sentia ha se yn se rigira.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
76 E perché meno ammiri la parola, 77 guarda il calor del sole che si fa vino, 78 giunto a l’omor che de la vite cola.
query.result:
**English:**
76 And so that you may marvel less at the word, 77 behold the heat of the sun which becomes wine, 78 joined to the moisture that flows from the vine.
**Cornish:**
76 Ha rag na vyth ammirya moy an ger, 77 gwel an gwres an howl a wra gwin, 78 joynt dhe'n omor a wra a'n win a gol.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
79 Quando Làchesis non ha più del lino, 80 solvesi da la carne, e in virtute 81 ne porta seco e l’umano e ’l divino:
82 l’altre potenze tutte quante mute; 83 memoria, intelligenza e volontade 84 in atto molto più che prima agute.
query.result:
**English:**
79 When Lachesis has no more thread, 80 it is loosed from the flesh, and in virtue 81 it carries with it both the human and the divine:
82 all the other powers are mute; 83 memory, intelligence, and will 84 are much sharper in action than before.
**Cornish:**
79 Pyw na vo Lachesis moy a'n lin, 80 a wra solvet a'n kig, ha yn virtudes 81 a wra gorra gans an humen ha'n divin:
82 An oll an possow erel a wra mut; 83 memor, intelligens, ha volonte 84 yn ober moy ages kyns a wra akut.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
85 Sanza restarsi, per sé stessa cade 86 mirabilmente a l’una de le rive; 87 quivi conosce prima le sue strade.
query.result:
**English:**
85 Without stopping, it falls by itself 86 wonderfully to one of the banks; 87 there it first learns its paths.
**Cornish:**
85 Heb gorra dhesist, rag y honan, a wra kodha 86 yn mirabyl dhe unn a'n fordhow; 87 enothoppya a wra konna y fordhow y honan kyns.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
88 Tosto che loco lì la circunscrive, 89 la virtù formativa raggia intorno 90 così e quanto ne le membra vive.
query.result:
**English:**
88 As soon as place circumscribes it there, 89 the formative power radiates around 90 just as and as much as in living members.
**Cornish:**
88 Kyns ages le mayth a wra syrcumskrivya enothoppya, 89 an virtudesober formativ a wra rajya a-dro, 90 kyns ha kemmys yn eseli byw.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
100 Però che quindi ha poscia sua paruta, 101 è chiamata ombra; e quindi organa poi 102 ciascun sentire infino a la veduta.
query.result:
**English:**
100 But because it has its appearance from there, 101 it is called shadow; and from there it then arranges 102 every sense, even to sight.
**Cornish:**
100 Mes rag wosa yma y parhesa, 101 gelwir skoodh; ha wosa yma wosa ytho 102 pub sens, bys dhe'n golwg.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
103 Quindi parliamo e quindi ridiam noi; 104 quindi facciam le lagrime e ’ sospiri 105 che per lo monte aver sentiti puoi.
query.result:
**English:**
103 Therefore we speak and therefore we laugh; 104 therefore we make the tears and the sighs 105 that you can have heard throughout the mountain.
**Cornish:**
103 Wosa yma yma ni a wra ha ni a hwer; 104 wosa yma yma ni a wra an deigrow ha'n golonnow 105 a ylli kewsel dre'n menydh.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
106 Secondo che ci affliggono i disiri 107 e li altri affetti, l’ombra si figura; 108 e quest’ è la cagion di che tu miri».
query.result:
**English:**
106 According to how desires afflict us 107 and the other emotions, the shadow takes shape; 108 and this is the reason why you see».
**Cornish:**
106 Avel orth an dysyryow a aflwyk ni 107 ha'n emosyonow erel, an skoodh a wra furvyes; 108 ha henna yw an acheson orth aga wra'th gweles».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
109 E già venuto a l’ultima tortura 110 s’era per noi, e vòlto a la man destra, 111 ed eravamo attenti ad altra cura.
query.result:
**English:**
109 And now, having come to the last torture 110 for us, he turned to the right hand, 111 and we were attentive to another concern.
**Cornish:**
109 Ha lemmyn, wosa dos ha'n diwettha pos 110 ragoni, ha troha dhe'n dhorn dhehwel, 111 ha ni a veu prederys dhe bys dhe aral gwayth.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
118 Lo duca mio dicea: «Per questo loco 119 si vuol tenere a li occhi stretto il freno, 120 però ch’errar potrebbesi per poco».
query.result:
**English:**
118 My leader said: «In this place 119 it is necessary to keep a tight rein on your eyes, 120 because one could easily go astray».
**Cornish:**
118 An myghtern vy a leveris: «Yn an le ma 119 yma yma ow tos dhe'n sel gwitha dhe'n lyga, 120 rag yth esa bosybyl dhe'n fordh dhehwel».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
127 Appresso il fine ch’a quell’ inno fassi, 128 gridavano alto: ‘Virum non cognosco’; 129 indi ricominciavan l’inno bassi.
query.result:
**English:**
127 Approaching the end that that hymn makes, 128 they cried out loudly: ‘I know not man’; 129 then they began the hymn again in low voices.
**Cornish:**
127 A-dhia dhe'n diwettha a wra'th henna kan dhe henna salm, 128 hwegh hwegh hwegh hwegh: ‘Virum non cognosco’; 129 wosa henna hwegh hwegh hwegh hwegh an salm a-dhia dhehwel.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
130 Finitolo, anco gridavano: «Al bosco 131 si tenne Diana, ed Elice caccionne 132 che di Venere avea sentito il tòsco».
query.result:
**English:**
130 Having finished it, they also cried out: «In the woods 131 Diana kept herself, and Helice hunted 132 who had heard the poison of Venus».
**Cornish:**
130 Wosa henna, hwegh hwegh hwegh hwegh: «Yn an koedh 131 Diana a veu dhe gadha, ha Elice a veu dhe hela, 132 ow a veu klevys dhe venym Venere».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
133 Indi al cantar tornavano; indi donne 134 gridavano e mariti che fuor casti 135 come virtute e matrimonio imponne.
query.result:
**English:**
133 Then they returned to singing; then women 134 and men cried out who were chaste outside 135 as virtue and marriage command.
**Cornish:**
133 Wosa henna, hwegh hwegh hwegh hwegh a-dhia dhe'n kanna; wosa henna gwregow 134 ha gwirosi a veu hwegh hwegh hwegh hwegh ow a veu dhe gadha 135 avel orth verthyans ha priodas a leveris.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Cornish.
136 E questo modo credo che lor basti 137 per tutto il tempo che ’l foco li abbruscia: 138 con tal cura conviene e con tai pasti
139 che la piaga da sezzo si ricuscia.
query.result:
**English:**
136 And I believe that this method is enough for them 137 for the entire time that the fire burns them: 138 with such care and with such meals it is necessary
139 that the wound eventually heals itself.
**Cornish:**
136 Ha henna'th fenten vythkredys ytholl 137 rag termyn bys vyth losow an tan 138 gans henna sor ha henna boesow
139 henna wonvos a wravyth y honan.
